question: Told ya to stay.
answer: I finished my chores. Where we goin'?

question: MacAndrews'. He was supposed to visit when the truce was over. Stay here. MacAndrews!... MacAndrews!? MacAndrews.
answer: Why would MacAndrews make so many scarecrows? R -- real!!!... Ahhhhhgggg!...

question: I can fight. They're coming!
answer: How many?

question: Three, maybe more!
answer: Armed?

question: They're English soldiers, ain't they?
answer: With your father and brother gone, they'll kill us and burn the farm!

question: It's up to us, Hamish! Not yet! Here he comes, be ready!
answer: Wanna stay with me tonight?

question: I wanna have supper waitin'.
answer: We'll get those English pigs tomorrow.

question: You were wise to hurry. We just had a funeral, isn't that what it means in England as well? My brother and nephew perished two days ago, when their hay cart turned over. They've been sanctified and buried in the holy rites of God's church, and any hand that disturbs them now takes on eternal damnation. So please -- do it. Funeral's over. Go home. Not that spoon, that one's for soup. Dip away from you. And don't slurp. We'll sleep here tonight. You'll come home with me. We'll let the house, and the lands too; plenty of willing neighbors.
answer: I don't want to leave.

question: Didn't want your father to die either, did ya? But it happened. Did the priest say anything about the Resurrection? Or was it all about Judgment?
answer: It was in Latin, sir.

question: Non loquis Latinum? You don't speak Latin? We have to fix that, won't we? Did he give the poetic benediction? The Lord bless thee and keep thee? Patris Benefactum et -- ...It was Malcolm's favorite.
answer: Good night, Uncle.

question: "The Lord bless thee and keep thee..."
answer: What are they doing?

question: Scotland! Scot-land! The French will grovel to anyone with strength! But how will they credit our strength when we cannot rule the whole of our own island?! Where is my son?
answer: Your pardon, M'lord, he asked me to come in his stead.

question: I sent for him -- and the little coward send you?!
answer: Shall I leave, M'lord?

question: What is it?!
answer: You directed me to report to you the moment the king's conference was ended.

question: So I did! And what was so important about it?
answer: Scotland. He intends -- He intends to grant --

question: Shut up, would you! How can I concentrate?!
answer: ...His majesty was quite keen that you should understand --

question: All so very boring! He wants me to learn to fight too, so let me do it! Stop there. Do you disapprove of Phillip?
answer: No, M'lord.

question: Look at me. I said LOOK AT ME! Now, my flower, do you understand?
answer: Yes. I had thought that... I was loathsome to you. Perhaps I am. If I may be excused, M'lord.

question: I hit it in the head. With a rock. Miz MacDougal. You look well. Hamish?
answer: Test of manhood.

question: You win.
answer: Call it a test of soldiery, then. The English won't let us train with weapons, so we train with stones.

question: The test of a soldier is not in his arm. It's here.
answer: No. It's here.

question: A contest, then. I still say this is no test. A catapult can throw a stone farther than a man can.
answer: That depends on the man.

question: Can you do it when it matters? As it matters in battle? Could you crush a man with that throw?
answer: I could crush you like a roach.

question: Then do it. Come, do it.
answer: You'll move

question: Would you honor me with a dance? He died in an accident, with my brother. Their cart turned over. Good evening, sir. May I speak with your daughter? Marion... Would you like to go for a ride on this fine evening? It's good Scottish weather, Madam, the rain is fallin' straight down. Your father doesn't like me, does he?
answer: It's not you. He dislikes that you're a Wallace. He just says... the Wallaces don't seem to live for very long.

question: Thank you for accepting.
answer: Thank you for inviting.

question: I'll invite you again, but your mother thinks I'm crazy.
answer: You are. And I'll come again.

question: Sir, I know it was strange of me to invite Marion to ride last night. I assure you, I --
answer: MacClannough's daughter is another matter. We come to fetch you to a meeting.

question: What kind of meeting?
answer: The secret kind. Your father was a fighter. And a patriot.

question: I know who my father was. I came back home to raise crops. And, God willing, a family. If I can live in peace, I will.
answer: You've been here before?

question: Some nights. I have dreams. Mostly dreams I don't want. I started riding at night to fill up my mind so that when I did sleep I'd dream only of the ride and the adventure.
answer: Did it work?

question: No. You don't choose your dreams. Your dreams choose you. I want... to marry you!
answer: I... accept your proposal!

question: I'm not just saying it!
answer: Nor I!

question: But I won't give you up to any nobleman.
answer: You scare me.

question: I don't want to scare you. I want to be yours, and you mine. Every night like this one.
answer: This night is too beautiful to have again.

question: I've missed you.
answer: Shush. It's only been a day. And it's seemed like forever.

question: Tonight then.
answer: My parents are growing suspicious! I can't keep meeting you every night!

question: Then when?
answer: ...Tonight!

question: What happened?
answer: ...girl.

question: What girl?!
answer: ...on horse.

question: The girl on the horse! Stop her!
answer: reaches the edge of the town and slips into the trees by the river; the soldiers are running every which way, but they've lost him. Thinking Marion's made it too, William heads deeper into the trees.

question: So this is the little whore he was fighting for.
answer: Marion!

question: You did. In Lanark village, the king's soldiers killed a girl. Her lover fought his way through the soldiers and killed the magistrate. He rebelled. He rebelled. He acted. He fought! Was it rage? Pride? Love? Whatever it was, he has more of it than I. I'm too arrogant to lie.
answer: Under whom?

question: A commoner named William Wallace.
answer: A commoner? So no one leads Scotland? You will embrace this rebellion. Support it, from our lands in the north. I will gain English favor by condemning it and ordering it opposed from our lands in the south. Whichever way the tide runs, we will rise.

question: This Wallace. He doesn't even have a knighthood. But he fights with passion, and he is clever. He inspires men.
answer: You admire him. Uncompromising men are easy to admire. He has courage. So does a dog. But you must understand this Press your case to the nobles. They will choose who rules Scotland.

question: Hamish, I... thank...
answer: What're ya doin'?

question: Thinking.
answer: Does it hurt?

question: Stop here and rest. Marion! Is... is it you? I'm dreaming.
answer: Yes, you are. And you must wake.

question: I don't want to wake. I want to stay with you.
answer: And I with you. But you must wake.

question: I need you so much! I love you!
answer: Wake up, William. Wake up!

question: They used hounds on us in Ireland, it's the only way!
answer: He's right, Hamish! Campbell! Divide them and run! Split again! No matter how we go, they follow. They have our scent. My scent.

question: We can't stop!
answer: They've tricked us.

question: What's the crazy man saying, Lord?
answer: The dogs have a scent. My scent. Someone must have given it to them.

question: Who would do such a thing?
answer: Exactly.

question: I thought I was dead when ya pulled that dagger!
answer: No English lord would trust an Irishman!

question: When the king returns he will bury them in those new clothes. Scotland is in chaos. Your husband is secretly sending an army north.
answer: How do you know this?

question: Last night I slept with a member of the War Council.
answer: He shouldn't be telling secrets in bed.

question: Ah, Oui! Englishmen don't know what a tongue is for.
answer: This Scottish rebel... Wallace? He fights to avenge a woman?

question: A magistrate wished to capture him, and found he had a secret lover, so he cut the girl's throat to tempt Wallace to fight -- and fight he did. Knowing his passion for his lost love, they next plotted to take him by desecrating the graves of his father and brother and setting an ambush at the grave of his wife. He fought his way through the trap and carried her body to a secret place! Now that is romance, Oui?
answer: ...I wouldn't know.

question: The Scots just stand in their formations!
answer: Steady! Hold... hold... NOW! FORM!

question: can see it; but worse is the SOUND, the SCREAMS OF DYING MEN AND HORSES, carried to him across the battlefield.
answer: Here I am, English coward! Come get me!!

question: LISTEN TO ME! Longshanks understands this! This! There is a difference between us. You think the people of this country exist to provide you with position. I think your position exists to provide the people with freedom. And I go to make sure they have it.
answer: Wait! ...I respect what you said. But remember, these men have lands, castles. Much to risk.

question: And the common man who bleeds on the battlefield, does he risk less?
answer: No. But from top to bottom this country has no sense of itself. Its nobles share allegiance with England and its clans war with each other. If you make enemies on both sides of the border, you'll end up dead.

question: We all end up dead. It's only a question of how. And why.
answer: I'm no coward! I want what you want! But we need the nobles.

question: I will stand up to him, and more.
answer: What news of the north?

question: Nothing new, Majesty. We have sent riders to speed any word.
answer: While I am in France fighting to expand your future kingdom I learn that Stirling castle is lost, our entire northern army wiped out! And you have done nothing?!

question: I have ordered conscriptions... Wallace has sacked York!
answer: Impossible. How dare you bring a panicky lie. If he can sack York, he can invade lower England. Edward, who is this shitpoker who speaks to me as if I needed his advice?

question: I have declared Phillip my High Counselor.
answer: You fight back at last! We must sue for a truce, and buy him off. But who will go to him? Not I. If I came under the sword of this murderer, I would end up like my nephew. And not you, the sight of my faggot son would only encourage an enemy to take over this country. So whom do I send?

question: Longshanks! I have come.
answer: I am the Princess of Wales.

question: Wife of Edward, the king's son?
answer: I come as the king's servant, and with his authority.

question: It's battle I want, not talk.
answer: But now that I am here, will you speak with a woman? I understand that you have recently been given the rank of knight.

question: I have been given nothing. God makes men what they are.
answer: Did God make you the sacker of peaceful cities? The executioner of the king's nephew, my husband's own cousin?

question: York was the staging point for every invasion of my country. And that royal cousin hanged a hundred Scots, even women and children, from the city walls.
answer: That is not possible.

question: Longshanks did far worse, the last time he took a Scottish city. I am no bandit. And I do not lie. Or in French if you prefer that
answer: Hamilton, leave us. Leave us now.

question: Let us talk plainly. You invade England. But you cannot complete the conquest, so far from your shelter and supply. The King proposes that you withdraw your attack. In return he grants you title, estates, and this chest with a thousand pounds of gold, which I am to pay to you personally.
answer: A Lordship. And gold. That I should become Judas.

question: Peace is made is such ways.
answer: SLAVES ARE MADE IN SUCH WAYS!

question: I understand you have suffered. I know... about your woman.
answer: She was my wife. We married in secret because I would not share her with an English lord. They killed her to get to me. And she was pregnant. I've never told anyone. I don't know why I tell you -- except because you look... much like her. And someday you will be a queen, and you must open your eyes! Tell your king that William Wallace will not be ruled. Nor will any Scot, while I live.

question: Sir. I leave this money, as a gift. Not from the king, but from myself. And not to you, but to the orphans of your country.
answer: My son's loyal wife returns, unkilled by the heathen. So he accepted our bribe.

question: No. He did not.
answer: Then why does he stay? My scouts say he has not advanced.

question: He waits. For you. He says he will attack no more towns -- if you are man enough to come fight him.
answer: You spoke with this Wallace in private. What kind of man is he?

question: ...A mindless barbarian. Not a king like you, M'lord.
answer: The Scottish nobles have sent him no support. His army starves. Our stall has worked, he must withdraw. You may return to your embroidery.

question: A thousand. You have made me Guardian of Scotland. So I tell you this is what we face.
answer: We must sue for peace.

question: Peace?!
answer: We cannot defeat this --

question: With cavalry -- not heavy, like the English, but light, fast horsemen, like you nobles employ -- we could outmaneuver their bowmen!
answer: It is suicide.

question: Sir William --
answer: We won at Stirling and still you quibbled! We won at York and you would not support us! Then I said nothing! Now I say you are cowards!

question: Please, Sir William! Speak with me alone! I beg you! You have achieved more than anyone dreamed. But fighting these odds looks like rage, not courage. Peace offers its rewards! Has war become a habit you cannot break?
answer: War finds me willing. I know it won't bring back all I have lost. But it can bring what none of us have ever had -- a country of our own. For that we need a king. We need you.

question: I am trying.
answer: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a man who believes only what others believe? Is he one who calculates the numbers for and against him but never weighs the strength in your own heart? There is strength in you. I see it. I know it.

question: I must... consult with my father.
answer: And I will consult with mine. Remember when the English turned their hounds on us? Maybe we should introduce them to our dogs.

question: Now we kill two birds at one stroke. We recruit from Scotland for our armies in France.
answer: The Scots will fight for us?

question: What choice do they have? Now they must serve us or starve.
answer: But if we have not caught Wallace --

question: You let Wallace escape your whole army. You cannot blame me for this.
answer: Good day to you, M'Lords.

question: You mock us with a smile?
answer: I am cheerful with a plan to soothe your miseries. All of England shudders with the news of renewed rebellion.

question: Wallace's followers.
answer: Wallace himself. If you wish to pretend a ghost rallies new volunteers in every Scottish town, I leave you to your hauntings. If you wish to take him, I know a way. I have faced him. Have you?

question: It does me good to see you.
answer: I am much diminished since we met.

question: There will be a new shipment of supplies coming north next month. Food and weapons. They will trav --
answer: No. Stop. I didn't come here for that.

question: Then why did you come?
answer: Why did you?

question: Because of the way you're looking at me now. The same way... as when we met. I know. You looked at me... and saw her. You must forgive me what I feel. No man has ever looked at me as you did.
answer: You have... you have a husband.

question: I have taken vows. More than one. I've vowed faithfulness to my husband, and sworn to give him a son. And I cannot keep both promises. You understand. Consider, before you laugh and say no. You will never own a throne, though you deserve one. But just as the sun will rise tomorrow, some man will rule England. And what if his veins ran not with the blood of Longshanks, but with that of a true king?
answer: I cannot love you for the sake of revenge.

question: May he rest in peace... You have already sealed the coffin?
answer: He was a modest man.

question: It will not be long before Longshanks too is encased in stone, and his crowns divided for others to wear. Our nobles are frightened and confused... Wallace has the commoners stirred up again, from the Highland clans to the lowland villages. In another six months Christ and the Apostles could not govern this country. Longshanks knows his son will scarcely be able to rule England, much less half of France. He needs Scotland settled, and he trusts you, after Falkirk. If you pay him homage, he will recognize you as king of Scotland. Our nobles have agreed to this as well.
answer: If I pay homage to another's throne, then how am I a king?

question: Homage is nothing. It is the crown that matters!
answer: The crown is that of Scotland. And Scotland is William Wallace.

question: That is another matter. There is a price to all this, required both by Longshanks and our nobles. Pay it, and you will be our king. And we will have peace. Sir William. We come to seek a meeting.
answer: You've all sworn to Longshanks.

question: An oath to a liar is no oath at all. An oath to a patriot is a vow indeed. Every man of us is ready to swear loyalty to you.
answer: So let the council swear publicly.

question: We cannot. Some scarcely believe you are alive. Other think you'll pay them Mornay's wages. We bid you to Edinburgh. Meet us at the city gates, two days from now, at sunset. Pledge us your pardon and we will unite behind you. Scotland will be one.
answer: I will meet you, but only one way -- if Robert the Bruce is there, and puts his hand on my Bible, and swears his loyalty to Scotland.

question: You know it's a trap.
answer: Probably. But we can't win alone. We know that. This is the only way.

question: I don't want to be a martyr.
answer: Nor I! I want to live! I want a home and children and peace. I've asked god for those things. But He's brought me this sword. And if He wills that I must lay it down to have what He wants for my country, then I'll do that too.

question: That's just a dream, William!
answer: We've lived a dream together. A dream of freedom!

question: Your dreams aren't about freedom! They're about Marion! You have to be a hero, because you think she sees you! Is that it?
answer: My dreams of Marion are gone. I killed them myself. If I knew I could live with her on the other side of death, I'd welcome it.

question: Keep these. We're going too.
answer: No. One of us is enough.

question: Treason. Against whom?
answer: Against thy king, thou vile fool! Hast thou anything to say?

question: Never, in my whole life, did I swear allegiance to your king --
answer: It matters not, he is thy king!

question: -- while many who serve him have taken and broken his oath many times. I cannot commit treason, if I have never been his subject!
answer: Confess, and you may receive a quick death. Deny, and you must be purified by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU CONFESS?!

question: I do not confess.
answer: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive they purification... And in the end, I promise you'll beg for the axe.

question: I am so afraid... Give me strength.
answer: I will see the prisoner. The king will be dead in a month! And his son is a weakling! Who do you think will rule this kingdom? Now OPEN THIS DOOR! Stop! Leave me! There is no way out of this hell! Leave me with him!

question: M'lady... what kindness of you to visit a stranger.
answer: Sir, I... come to beg you to confess all, and swear allegiance to the king, that he might show you mercy.

question: Will he show mercy to my country? Will he take back his soldiers, and let us rule ourselves?
answer: Mercy... is to die quickly. Perhaps even live in the Tower. In time, who knows what can happen, if you can only live.

question: If I swear to him, then everything I am is dead already. Your people are lucky to have a princess so kind that she can grieve at the death of a stranger.
answer: You will die! It will be awful!

question: Every man dies. Not every man really lives.
answer: Drink this! It will dull your pain.

question: It will numb my wits, and I must have them all. If I'm senseless, or if I wail, then Longshanks will have broken me.
answer: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it! I have come to beg for the life of William Wallace.

question: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it! I have come to beg for the life of William Wallace.
answer: You fancy him.

question: I respect him. At worst he was a worthy enemy. Show mercy... Oh thou great king... and win the respect of your own people. Even now, you are incapable of mercy? Nor you. To you that word is as unfamiliar as love.
answer: Before he lost his powers of speech, he told me his one comfort was that he would live to know Wallace was dead.
